    • pok

    Guidance for AI coding agents working on gp

    Purpose - Help contributors and AI agents quickly understand the gp R package layout, developer workflows, and project-specific conventions.

    Big picture - This package implements Gaussian Process modelling in R. Core logic lives in R/ (model constructors, fitting, prediction). See examples in examples/ and vignette vignettes/pok.Rmd. - Data flow: user supplies named list of data.frames -> gpData() constructs a gpData object -> gp() builds a model from a formula and gpData -> gpFit() fits hyperparameters and stores large precomputed matrices in gp$fit -> pred() / predict.gp() produce predictions.

    Key files to inspect - R/gp.R - model constructor and high-level checks. - R/gpData.R - data conventions: grouping factors (attr(df, "fact")), main table rules, gpDataPrepare() scaling behavior. - R/gpFit.R - fitting workflow; two-stage optimization and how gpPack()/gpUnpack() are used to strip/add precomputed matrices. - R/gpHyperpar.R - hyperparameter table format and helpers (gpHyperparExportVector, gpHyperparImportVector). - R/pred.R and R/predict.gp.R - prediction behavior, chunking (maxn), and caching hooks (Kx.cache, Kxx.cache). - R/cov_funcs.R and R/cov.*.R - covariance functions and hyperparameter definitions.

    Project-specific conventions (important for automated edits) - Data input: gpData() expects a named list of data.frames. Tables that represent different record types must carry attr(df, "fact") with a column of that name. The special factor name "1" denotes “no grouping factor”. See R/gpData.R for exact validation rules. - Scaling: gpDataPrepare() performs scaling for matrices where gp$dataReq$mats[[m]]$scaling is TRUE and preserves training scaling for new data. - Hyperparameters: stored in a tibble-like table (gp$hyperpar) with columns component, hyperpar, start, value, low, up, fixed, optim.link, prior. Use gpHyperparExportVector()/gpHyperparImportVector() to convert between optimizer vectors and the table. - Saving models: precomputed matrices in gp$fit make objects large. Call gpPack() before saving to disk and gpUnpack() when loading for reuse. - Two-stage fit: gpFit() implements a stage1/stage2 flow for sigma2 parameters. Be careful when modifying optimization flow; tests/examples assume this behavior.

    Performance & runtime notes - Prediction may split large prediction sets using pred(..., maxn = ). Use Kx.cache/Kxx.cache hooks to avoid recomputing expensive kernels. - Many functions expect gpUnpack() to have been run (e.g., fit$L, fit$W, fit$K). If code manipulates gp$fit, preserve these names or call gpUnpack().

    Developer workflow (quick commands) - Iterative development: open R and run: - devtools::load_all() to reload package code - devtools::document() to regenerate man pages from roxygen - # use examples/ and vignettes/ for runnable examples

    Editing patterns to follow - Prefer modifying or adding helper functions in R/ and keep public API stable (gp(), gpFit(), pred()/predict.gp()). - When adding new covariance hyperparameters, update R/cov_funcs.R (hyperpar definition), and adjust default table generation in R/gpHyperpar.R.

    What to watch for in PRs - Breaking changes to gpData() semantics (grouping factor behavior) or gp$hyperpar table shape. - Changes that alter the two-stage optimization logic in R/gpFit.R (stage1low, start/value handling). - Any modification that changes names or presence of gp$fit elements (L, W, a, K, f) without providing gpPack()/gpUnpack() compatibility.

    Where to run tests & examples - Examples: examples/ (scripts). Vignette: vignettes/pok.Rmd. - There is no formal tests/ directory; prefer running representative examples via R interactive session or creating small reproducible examples under examples/.

    If anything in this file is unclear, tell me which part to expand with concrete examples or add links to specific lines.
